newsitem.title: DENMARK: Danish Industry Ministry drops shipbuilding probe.
newsitem.headline: Danish Industry Ministry drops shipbuilding probe.

text.p: Denmark's industry minister Mimi Jacobsen presented on Wednesday a new ministry report concluding that her ministry's administration of shipbuilding aid in the period 1986-95 was in accordance with European Union rules.
"The report show that EU's aid ceilings have not been exceeded," Jacobsen said at a news conference.
At the same time Jacobsen said she was dropping a planned legal probe into state shipbuilding aid, rejecting the findings of a critical independent study accusing the government of illegalities.

Jacobsen said her ministry had studied 308 cases of aid granted to Danish shipbuilding yards in the period 1986-1995 and found that the report's critical stance was unfounded and full of errors and misinterpretations of European Union rules.

The study, commissioned by the ministry and carried out by international accountancy firm Coopers & Lybrand, criticised changing Danish governments for subsidising the sector to the tune of four billion crowns ($697 million) between 1986-1995.
Based on a random sample of 58 cases, it accused the governments of illegalities, irregularities and granting aid to yards in breach of international rules.

Jacobsen said 10 borderline cases of state loans being granted for Norwegian and Swedish shipping companies to build vessels at six minor Danish yards in 1986-87 were erroneously not referred to the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development but that this had been discussed with the Commission.
"We have checked Cooper & Lybrand's survey in depth, now our report will be forwarded to the European Commission," she said.
The Cooper & Lybrand study was roundly attacked by the Danish Shipbuilders Association and A.P. Moeller, Denmark's leading shipping, oil and gas group, when it came out in May this year.
In July the European Commission announced plans to investigate Danish shipbuilding aid after seeing the study, fearing that Denmark's ship subsidies might have exceeded EU limits in the period.

The Commission said in a statement then that judging from the Cooper & Lybrand study, there were indications that vessels were financed during the period on the basis of an inflated price level "which has created a risk that the state aid ceiling was exceeded."

Denmark, its shipbuilding industry in crisis, is a major opponent of state subsidising and Danish shipbuilders, backed by the government, have filed a suit in the European Court of Justice against the Commission over shipbuilding subsidies to east German yards.
